title: WCAS PSYCH 381-0-20 Children & the Law
class_attributes:
Social & Behavioral Sciences Distro Area

Attendance at 1st class mandatory

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will address a variety of issues pertaining to children's involvement in the legal system in roles such as decision-makers, witnesses, victims, and perpetrators. Among the topics we may cover are:
? the legal status, rights, and responsibilities of juveniles
? children and custody proceedings
? physical and sexual abuse of children
? children as witnesses
? juvenile culpability as perpetrators
? development of criminal behavior
? the juvenile justice system and developmental psychology
? treatment and punishment of juvenile offenders

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Psych 205-Research Methods in Psychology AND Psych 218-Developmental Psychology

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion-based seminar, some very short lectures, films, group presentations

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation in discussion, weekly written discussion questions, finding and summarizing empirical research studies, and one 10-15 page independent research proposal with literature review.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will use a variety of journal articles, law review articles, legal cases, and book chapters from the fields of psychology and law.

Students will most likely need to purchase two books in addition to the assembled readings:
1.) Ayers, W. (1997). A kind and just parent: The children of juvenile court. Boston, MA: Beacon. [ISBN: 0807044032, approximate cost $17.00]

2.) Scott, E.S., & Steinberg, L. (2008). Rethinking juvenile justice. Cambridge, MA: Harvard. ISBN: 978-0-674-05746-3.
